Developer’s Manual¶

Overview¶

There are two components doing the job:

  • the shell script as controller, making entries, calling the parser and sending reports.
  • the parser creating the xlsx files

files and formats¶

The controller files are stored in ~/.tick/ where a protocol.csv is created.

csv format¶

The csv follows the standard format of comma separated values [1].

  • tag
  • year
  • month
  • day
  • duration in seconds
  • from unixtime
  • to unixtime
  • description

It is not neccessary that both duration and from/to are set but if they are those two times spans are validated against each other.

available tags¶

Tags available in version 0.1a are:

tag string meaning
~ Comment
e Entry
h Holiday
c Overtime Compensation
i Illness
o Offset

offset is used to add holidays or working hours to account.

[1]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comma-separated_values

xlsx scheme¶

The excel file consists of roughly 3 Parts:

  • Header with
    • Name
    • Month
    • Overview
  • Body
  • Footer with
    • legend
    • infoline containing technical informations like parsing date and so on

Legacy Formats¶

The predecessor etime used two files:

  • the tracker put the data of a month into ~/.etime/<YY-MM.elog whith each line in the form <DD> <duration in hours in float> <description>
  • when parsing two files where created:
    • a csv with each line of the form <DD>.<MM>.;<Duration in float, comma as separator>;"<description>"
    • a xlsx containing a bare, unsorted list with full dates

configuration¶

Configuration is hard coded. Change the email address the report is sent to in the shell script.

Components¶

Controller¶

Parser¶

API¶

Parser¶

parser¶

parser for tick

parser.parse_csv_protocol(protocol)[source]¶

parse a list of csv protocol entries into year. return year.

Parameters:protocol (Union[list, tuple]) – protocol to parse

Warning

missing months are not padded. The protocol.Month resulting from the protocol.Month.get_next() method is adjusted to reflect the next month in chain

Return type:dict

protocol¶

This module provides the Month and Year classes

class protocol.Month(year: int = 0, month: int = 0, holidays_left: int = 0, working_hours_account: int = 0, hours_worth_working_day: int = 4)[source]¶

Provides the work time protocol for one month

Parameters:
  • holidays_left (int) – number of holidays left, 0 if omitted
  • working_hours_account (int) – credit of working hours in seconds, 0 if omitted
  • yearmonth – integer of the form [[YY]YY]MM. Current time if omitted. Current year if only month is given. 20th century if first two digits are missing.
  • hours_worth_working_day (int) – number of hours a working day is worth If only one digit is given it will be padded with a leading 0.
Raises:

InvalidDateException – raised when the Date given is nonsense.
append(tag, day, duration=0, from_unixtime=0, to_unixtime=0, description=None)[source]¶

append an entry to the protocol

Parameters:
  • tag (str) – tag
  • duration (int) – duration of work in seconds
  • from_unixtime (int) – beginning of work in epoch
  • to_unixtime (int) – ending of work in epoch
  • description (Optional[str]) – description
Raises:

ConfusingData – when duration and from/to do are both given and do not match
Return type:

Month

class protocol.Season(holidays_left=0, working_hours_account=0)[source]¶

A Season contains several Months in the same preset.

A preset is the set of monthly_target, holidays and working_hours_account Normally this should apply to a year

add_month(month)[source]¶

add a protocol to :var:`self.protocols` :param protocol: protocol to add. self.protocols[protocol.month] = protocol

Return type:Season
validate()[source]¶

validate the chain of months

Raises:ValueError – when validation fails
Return type:Season
